sops.title: SOP 1: Proving Similarity (AA Criterion)
sops.goal: Prove two triangles are similar using Angle-Angle
steps: Identify the two triangles: Label vertices clearly (e.g., △ABC and △DEF)
Find two pairs of equal angles: Use properties like vertically opposite angles, corresponding angles, alternate angles, or angles in the same segment
State the equal angles explicitly: Write ∠ABC = ∠DEF and ∠BAC = ∠EDF with reasons
Conclude using AA: State 'Since two angles are equal, △ABC is similar to △DEF (AA)'

pitfalls.text: Not providing geometric reasons for why angles are equal
Mixing up corresponding vertices when stating similarity

pro_tips: Common angle reasons: vertically opposite, corresponding (parallel lines), alternate (parallel lines), angles in same segment
Always write the triangle correspondence correctly: △ABC ~ △DEF means A↔D, B↔E, C↔F

sops.title: SOP 2: Proving Congruency (SAS, SSS, ASA, RHS)
steps: Identify the two triangles: Label all vertices
List what you know: Mark equal sides and angles on the diagram
Determine which test applies: SAS (Side-Angle-Side), SSS (Side-Side-Side), ASA (Angle-Side-Angle), or RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side)
State the equal elements with reasons: e.g., 'AB = DE (given)', '∠ABC = ∠DEF (common angle)'
Conclude: State '△ABC ≅ △DEF (SAS)' with the appropriate criterion

pitfalls.text: Using the wrong congruency criterion (e.g., trying to use AAA)
For SAS, the angle must be BETWEEN the two equal sides

pro_tips: SAS: The angle must be included between the two sides
Common reasons: 'common side', 'given', 'opposite equal angles', 'radii of same circle'
ASA vs AAS: For ASA, the side must be between the two angles

sops.title: SOP 3: Using Similarity to Find Unknown Lengths
sops.goal: Calculate unknown side lengths using similar triangles
steps: Confirm similarity: Either it's stated or prove it using SOP 1
Set up the ratio: Write corresponding sides as a proportion. e.g., AB/DE = BC/EF = AC/DF
Substitute known values: Plug in all given lengths
Solve for unknown: Cross-multiply if needed, then isolate the unknown
Check reasonableness: Does the answer make geometric sense?

pitfalls.text: Setting up ratios with non-corresponding sides
Inverting the ratio (getting it upside down)

pro_tips: Draw the triangles separately if they overlap, matching corresponding vertices
Write the similarity statement first (△ABC ~ △DEF) to ensure correct correspondence
